title: Reasoning on crowd-sourced semantic annotations to facilitate cataloguing of 3D artefacts in the cultural heritage domain
segmentation: This is a completely different topic that I didn't cover this morning and it's actually the work of a PhD student.
David you chee.
How you and shooter Grocer who many of you know as well.
It's a collaboration between the UQE Research Lab, Microsoft Research Asia, the UQ Anthropology Museum, and the Antiquities Museum, and we got funding from Microsoft E Heritage Grant Anna UQ.
Major equipment and infrastructure grant.

So the objective is to combine low level crowdsourced semantic annotations with a number of automatically extracted features to describe the parts of the object in order to infer high level tags which enable classification of the artifact.
The goal, the reason why we want to do this is clearly becausw.
Museum curation is an expensive, time consuming process and so we want to make it faster and simple.
We want to enable authentication of artifacts and also it has a secondary purpose which is an E learning tool for anthropology students.
So the.
Case study that we worked on is quite a simple one.

There are a lot more complex examples than this and the case studies Greek vases from the UQ Antiquities Museum and we chose those because they have a very prescriptive way of classification and I'll explain that.

But we used another tool that we developed that David developed called the 3DS, a tool which is the 3D semantic annotation tool, and it's a web based annotation tool for 3D objects that allows you to annotate points, surface regions or segments of 3D objects.
It's built on top of the open annotation data model so that it's interoperable across clients and also across formats.
And we use 3DS eight.
Label the parts.
So here is some examples.
So en IK M4, which is the top shape up there is defined by an Oval body and offset neck with a thick mouth, two vertical handles and a heavy stand.
A stemness has around body and offset short neck with a wide mouth to loop handles and a heavy stand and a lekythos has a tall cylindrical body with an offset shoulder at all neck.
Heavy mouth, one vertical handle and a heavy stand.
So by using these kinds of rules which are defining the size and shape of parts of the object, you can infer the class of that boss.
So we defined a set of swirl rules to infer the high level class from low level features.
So for example, if object A is tagged with disc shaped mouth, round body, broad handle, and black figure polyestrous seen it's a Corinthian aryballos.
At least we have a pretty high probability that it's going to be that.
So we.
Modified the 3DS.

With these kinds of tags we define the inferencing rules.

I'm not sure how you pronounce it.
Is it Euler or Ula ula?
No anyway, reasoning engine to that in further high level tags and then we did some usability studies in the evaluations looking at the quality of the results.
The objects themselves were generated using a Konica Minolta Vivid nine eye laser scanner.

Now we have to get rid of it, but this is what was used originally.
It generates very quite high resolution.
Polygonal mesh objects?

Anyway, that's the work flowy.
Need that these are the polygonal mesh objects that it generates and then you do texture mapping on.

And David converts those objects to X 3D format and what he's also done is taken the open annotation data model and extended it for 3D objects so that a particular urri which points to an object which is the target of an annotation is constrained by some X 3D constraints.
So those X 3D constraints might be a next Y&Z point on the object.
It might be a 3 dimensional surface area, or it might be a 3 dimensional volumetric segment.

And we also took the Seahawks, ERM ontology and extended that for Greek pottery to define pottery, parts and surface decorations so you can see a Greek boss has a rim elip a mouth and neck, handle, a shoulder abadia stem afoot base.
So we're not identifying those parts automatically.
We used 3DS a tool.
To do that?
This describes the system architecture where we have a.
It's based on Drupal.
At the back end there's a file store we're using open RDF sesame for the annotations themselves, and we're using the EULA.
Yep, reasoning engine.
So this is what the web interface looks like, so you can go in and search or browse particular obj.
And then you bring up a particular object, and then you can, using our tool annotate.
As I said, either a surface region or a volumetric segment or a point.
And you attach annotations to it.
Here it shows the interface for annotating a handle and associating black cylindrical handle with that volumetric segment.
And then we define the rules using N3 logic.
This shows here that let's see.
Greek pottery.
It has a part.
This one has a part of a body handle one handle to a mouth and a foot.
The measurement of it has to be less than 300.
I think that's millimeters.
The body has to be small and deep and bowl shaped handle one should be vertical.
Handle two should be horizontal.
The mouth should be wide, the foot thin, and if those characteristics apply, it says skyphos Type B files.
And then we also enable you to attach different weightings to different features.
So the most important thing for Schiff has Part B maybe.
Well in this case you can see that the bowl shaped body has awaiting of 1 and the wide mouth as if waiting of 1 and the thin foot has a weighting of 1.
So here we can, applying weightings you can say which parts in which features are the most significant for identifying that particular type of ours.

Is using the annotation client they invoke the inference that then calls the eye reasoner, which then goes and gets the latest rules, applies it to the object and then retrieves the results?
This is what the results look like for this particular object.

OK. OK, there is some sound, but I'll I think it's better.
It's just music so.
This is just a video showing the annotation tool being used.
And this is the Skittles type B Cup.
So you load the object and it's just a web browser.
There's no plug in that you need to.
This is we're using HTML5 and X3, D. And then we can look at existing.
Annotations.
And then you can, and so this is now an example of annotating the handle on the left.
And you said it's a volume metric segment, so it cuts through and annotates the whole.
That segment of the 3D polygonal mesh.
And then you click on that and then you attach.
Annotation to it using our ontology.
So pull down menu and here it's a vertical handle.
I think now we're going to show annotating a surface region.
And you can clean up these annotations if, for example, it picks up extra polygons.
It's very easy just to clean up the annotation.
So once you've defined the region, then you attach the annotation.
And again it's pulling down menu pull down menu from our ontology.
OK, what's happening now.
Now we're going to look at the classification of this object itself.
So you can either we gave the users two choices.
They can either choose a shape from a list of shapes here and they have to compare this object with those shapes, or they can use our reasoning engine to actually.
Do a comparison from our tags with the rules and it gives you a ranked list of what's the most likely candidate and the top candidate is a skip ostype be from the ranked list based on the tags.
Now.
We also David recently has been looking at opening up multiple objects, enabling comparative analysis between these objects and you can segment particular parts.
So here we're looking at the volume.
Of the bowl for each of these verses, and doing comparative analysis between them, and so the system allows you to do automatically.
Measurement of length or distance is surface areas or volumes and do comparative analysis between these objects and then here it automatically infers relationships between them based on the size.
So object A is bigger than object B is bigger than object C, so we're inferring I guess, size, relationships and other types of relationships based on automatic detection.
OK, so.
OK, so.
Once we've done these automatic inferencing of high level tags, then it enables richer search and browse so you can search on full text and the metadata associated with these objects.
You can search on the tags and keywords and you'll retrieve the object with the highlighted annotation.

You can search on features such as give me all the vases with horizontal handles you can search on the classes of the vases, but you can also search on associations or relationships between these objects.
So give me all the objects that are similar to this.
Give me all the objects that are bigger than this.
We also performed evaluation of our reasoning.
This shows that given, say, 100K triples, 50 types of objects and a certain number of triples, our approach was consistently faster than a first order logic approach.
If you read the paper, you can see our approach is a probabilistic approach that uses Markov logic.
So our approach is faster than the 1st order logic approach both for.
50 types of objects and also for a million triples and as the number of objects increases were still consistently faster than the 1st order logic approach.

The other thing that was interesting is that the 1st order logic using that for reasoning is very sensitive to the ordering of the statements in the rules, so the ordering of the statements all have to be same in the rules.

If they're not, then we find that the 1st order logic speed increases rapidly, so you can see there in columns three and four 4 rules with the two statements switched 1st order logic rapidly increases with regards to the.
The time it takes to return results.

Our approach is also better because if there's any information missing with regard to tagging of the vases, the candidates are not just marked as false negative, they're just lower in the ranking order, so they're less likely.
We
Data usability study and we had 18 users had to classify 6 objects.

They had to either use this manual classification where they compare the object shape with this big list or they used our reasoning tool and they found that the manual classification was quite onerous and they preferred the rank list of choices.

User feedback is that they'd like to be able to see multiple selected objects or from the same viewpoint and magnification they'd like to be able to overlay multiple objects over each other with different levels of transparency as well as on shapes so you can compare it on the shapes they want to automatically calculate differences in lengths and areas and volumes between segments, and they'd like to be able to automatically do statistical analysis over a set of selected objects or parts.
For example, give me the mean and standard deviation of mouth diameters for this set of vases.
Future work we want to provide a simple user interface so users can define an edit these rules.
At the moment we define them ourselves based on conversations with the experts and based on articles that we read.
There's a number of web based documents which define these kinds of rules for these verses.
We can't know.
We can automatically extract dimensions, but not shape and color.
So if we can do that, then things like you know it's a horizontal and also the axis of the handles.
If we can extract shape and color it will be even more automated.
We'd like to be able to infer classification through our Association annotations.
So if object A is similar to object be an object, B is a Corinthian aryballos, then we can assume.
Object A is a Corinthian aryballos, and that's the annotating.
Relationships between parts.
Um acknowl
Payments to David you, who's the PhD student?
The Antiquities Museum who gave us the vases or access to the vases and also their knowledge about Greek bars is Microsoft Research, Asia Uku, major equipment and infrastructure.

Grab the Andrew Mellon Foundation were the ones who funded the open annotation collaboration work that we did with Tim Cole, Herbert, vendor Sample and Roberts Anderson that is now moved into the W 3C.
And if you want to find out more, it's that's the web address.
But if you type in 3D SANUQ, it should come up.
This, David you, that's his contact details.
Tutor is tutoring the room somewhere chews up the back and that's my contact details.
If you have any other further queries.
Thank you.
